etymology.description: Corruption of 匄(匄) (gài, original meaning unknown) -> final form 丐(丐) (gài, 'beggar')
etymology.interpretation: 丐(丐) (gài) is derived from 匄(匄), which originally had an unknown meaning, possibly 'to damage'. Over time, 丐(丐) evolved into its current use to mean 'beggar'. The transformation appears to involve a simplification or corruption of the original form, indicating a shift in both form and meaning.

examples.chinese: 街上有个丐(街上有個丐)，他四处讨饭(他四處討飯)。
examples.pinyin: Jiē shàng yǒu gè gài, tā sì chù tǎo fàn.
examples.english: There is a beggar on the street, and he begs for food everywhere.

examples.chinese: 他曾是繁华都市边缘的丐(他曾是繁華都市邊緣的丐)，今日落魄街头(今日落魄街頭)。
examples.pinyin: Tā céng shì fán huá dū shì biān yuán de gài, jīn rì luò pò jiē tóu.
examples.english: He used to be a beggar on the outskirts of a bustling city, but today he is destitute on the street.
